docTitle.titlePart:
Mr VVILLIAM
SHAKESPEARES
COMEDIES,
HISTORIES, &
TRAGEDIES.
Publiſhed according to the True Originall Copies.

titlePage.docImprint: London : Printed by Isaac Iaggard, and Ed. Blount [at the charges of W. Iaggard, Ed. Blount, I. Smithweeke, and W. Aspley]., 1623.

foliation.p: Numbering peculiarities: 1st count: p.50 misnumbered 58; p.59 misnumbered 51; p.86 misnumbered 88; p.153 misnumbered 151; p.161 misnumbered] 163; p.164 misnumbered 162; p. 165 misnumbered 163; p. 189 misnumbered 187; p. 249 misnumbered 251; p.250 misnumbered 252; p. 265 misnumbered 273 -- 2nd count: p.37 misnumbered 39 in some copies; p.89 misnumbered 91; p. 90 misnumbered 92 -- 3rd count: p.165-166 numbered 167 and 168 respectively; p. 216 numbered 218 -- 5th count: p. 279 misnumbered 259; p. 282 misnumbered 280; p.308 misnumbered 38; p. 379 misnumbered 389; p. 399 misnumbered 993.

collation.p: The signatures varies between sources, with the most commonly cited being Hinman's and West's: 1. Hinman: πA⁶ (πA1+1) [πB²], ²A-2B⁶ 2C² a-g⁶ χgg⁸ h-v⁶ x⁴ χ1.2 [para.]-2[para.]⁶ 3[para]¹ aa-ff⁶ gg² Gg⁶ hh⁶ kk-bbb⁶; 2. West: πA⁶ (πA1+1, πA5+1.2)²A-2B⁶ 2C² a-g⁶ ²g⁸ h-v⁶ x⁴ 'gg3.4' (±'gg3') [para.]-2[para.]⁶ 3[para]¹ 2a-2f⁶ 2g² 2G⁶ 2h⁶ 2k-2v⁶ x⁶ 2y-3b⁶.
Mis-signed leaves: a3 mis-signed Aa3; ³gg1 mis-signed Gg; nn1-nn2 mis-signed Nn and Nn2 and oo1 mis-signed Oo.
"The life and death of King Iohn" begins new pagination on leaf a1 recto; "The tragedy of Coriolanus" begins new pagination on leaf aa1 recto.

supportDesc.condition: Lacks A1, the letterpress frontispiece entitled "To the reader". The title page is trimmed and mounted, with a section of the mount towards the foot of the leaf mutilated resulting in the loss of some the Droechout imprint at the bottom left hand corner of the portrait and the central section of an early MS note. For a full condition report, including a full survey of damage and repairs, please contact Rare Books.

layout.p: Colophon reads: "Printed at the charges of W. Iaggard, Ed. Blount, I. Smithweeke, and W. Aspley. 1623.".
Editors’ dedication signed: Iohn Heminge. Henry Condell.

decoDesc.decoNote: With an engraved title-page portrait of the author signed: "Martin- Droeshout: sculpsit· London.". The plate exists in 2 states: 1. The earlier state has lighter shading generall ; 2. Later state has heavier shading, especially around the collar, and minor differences particularly with the jawline and moustache. The vast majority of surviving copies have the plate in the second state which has led some scholars to conclude that the earlier state was a proof. The portrait in this copy is the second state.

additions.p: Two MS verses on first endpaper verso: 1. 9 lines of verse by an unknown author, first line reads "An active swain to make a leap was seen". 2. A copy of Ben Jonson’s printed "To the Reader"; MS note on t.p. (mutilated) appears to read "Honest [Shakes]peare". Minor annotations on leaf 2n4 (Macbeth). All in an early English hand, presumably added after leaving the Library.

bindingDesc.p: Seventeenth-century (1624) English (Oxford) smooth calf. Bound for the Bodleian Library by William Wildgoose, with evidence of two cloth ties, red sprinkled edge. Formerly chained, with evidence of chain staple at the head of the upper cover. Remains of paper label at the head of the spine. Enclosed in 20th century book box by Maltby of Oxford. See S. Gibson in Original Bodleian Copy of First Folio, p. 12-13. One of four items sent out on 17th February 1624 for binding by Wildgoose containing printed waste from a copy of Cicero’s "De Officiis, et al." [Deventer: Richard Pafraet, between 1480 and 1485] as paste-downs. For more information on this work see: Bod. Inc. Cat., C-322.

origin.p: For further details on the printing of this item see Hinman, Charleton. The printing and proof-reading of the First Folio of Shakespeare: Oxford, 1963.

acquisition.p: Acquired by the Bodleian in 1623, presumably in sheets. It was sent out to William Wildgoose on 17 February 1624 for binding (see: Library Records e.258, fol. 48r) and upon its return chained in Duke Humfrey at shelfmark S 2.17 Art. It is listed in the Bodleian’s 1635 catalogue of printed books but was gone by the publication of the next catalogue in 1674, replaced by the newer Third Folio (1664). There is no explicit reference in Library Records to the disposal of this copy, but there is a record of a sale of "superfluous library books" to Richard Davis, a bookseller in Oxford, in 1664 for the sum of £24.

After leaving the Bodleian this copy entered the collection of Richard Turbutt of Ogston Hall, Derbyshire at some point in the early 18th century. It stayed in the family’s possession until 1906, when it was reacquired by the Bodleian for the sum of £3000, raised by public subscription. For a full discussion of the rediscovery and purchase of this copy see: F. Madan, G. M. R. Turbutt and S. Gibson, The Original Bodleian Copy of the First Folio of Shakespeare (theTurbutt Shakespeare) (Oxford, 1905)
For a full discussion of this copy and the digital version see http://shakespeare.bodleian.ox.ac.uk/ and West and Rasmussen (2011), 31.

listBibl.bibl: Digital facsimile images available at: http://firstfolio.bodleian.ox.ac.uk/.

person.persName: Duke of Milan, father to Silvia
Eglamour, agent for Silvia in her escape
Speed, a clownish servant to Valentine
Thurio, a foolish rival to Valentine

sp.speaker: Valentine.
sp.l: CEase to perswade, my louing Protheus:
Home‑keeping youth, haue euer homely wits,
Wer't not affection chaines thy tender dayes
To the sweet glaunces of thy honour'd Loue,
I rather would entreat thy company,
To see the wonders of the world abroad,
Then (liuing dully sluggardiz'd at home)
Weare out thy youth with shapelesse idlenesse,
But since thou lou'st; loue still, and thriue therein,
Euen as I would, when I to loue begin.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Wilt thou be gone? Sweet Valentine, adew,
Thinke on thy Protheus, when thou (hap'ly) seest
Some rare note‑worthy object in thy trauaile.
Wish me partaker in thy happinesse,
When thou do'st meet good hap; and in thy danger,
(If euer danger doe enuiron thee)
Commend thy grieuance to my holy prayers,
For I will be thy beades‑man, Vaelentine.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.p: And on a loue‑booke pray for my successe?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: Vpon some booke I loue, I'le pray for thee.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.l: That's on some shallow Storie of deepe loue,
How yong Leander crost the Hellespont.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: That's a deepe Storie, of a deeper loue;
For he was more then ouer‑shooes in loue.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: 'Tis true; for you are ouer‑bootes in loue,
And yet you neuer swom the Hellespont.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: Ouer the Bootes? nay giue me not the Boots.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: No, I will not; for it boots thee not.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.l:
To be in loue; where scorne is bought with
(grones:
Coy looks, with hart‑sore sighes: one fading moments mirth,
With twenty watchfull, weary, tedious nights;
If hap'ly won, perhaps a haplesse gaine;
If lost, why then a grieuous labour won;
How euer: but a folly bought with wit,
Or else a wit, by folly vanquished.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: So, by your circumstance, you call me foole.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.p: So, by your circumstance, I feare you'll proue.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: 'Tis loue you cauill at, I am not Loue.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Loue is your master, for he masters you;
And he that is so yoked by a foole,
Me thinkes should not be chronicled for wise.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Yet Writers say; as in the sweetest Bud,
The eating Canker dwels; so eating Loue
Inhabits in the finest wits of all.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And Writers say; as the most forward Bud
Is eaten by the Canker ere it blow,
Euen so by Loue, the yong, and tender wit
Is turn'd to folly, blasting in the Bud,
Loosing his verdure, euen in the prime,
And all the faire effects of future hopes.
But wherefore waste I time to counsaile thee
That art a votary to fond desire?
Once more adieu: my Father at the Road
Expects my comming, there to see me ship'd.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: And thither will I bring thee, Valentine.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Sweet Protheus, no: Now let vs take our leaue:
To Millaine let me heare from thee by Letters
Of thy successe in loue; and what newes else
Betideth here in absence of thy Friend:
And I likewise will visite thee with mine.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: All happinesse bechance to thee in Millaine.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: As much to you at home: and so farewell.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: He after Honour hunts, I after Loue;
He leaues his friends, to dignifie them more;
I loue my selfe, my friends, and all for loue;
Thou, Iulia thou hast metamorphis'd me:
Made me neglect my Studies, loose my time;
Warre with good counsaile; set the world at nought;
Made Wit with musing, weake; hart sick with thought.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Sir Protheus: 'saue you: saw you my Master?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: But now he parted hence to embarque for Millain.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.l: Twenty to one then, he is ship'd already,
And I haue plaid the Sheepe in loosing him.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Indeed a Sheep doth very often stray,
And if the Shepheard be awhile away.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p:
You conclude that my Master is a Shepheard then,
and I Sheepe?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: I doe.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p:
Why then my hornes are his hornes, whether I
wake or sleepe.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: A silly answere, and fitting well a Sheepe.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: This proues me still a Sheepe.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: True: and thy Master a Shepheard.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Nay, that I can deny by a circumstance.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: It shall goe hard but ile proue it by another.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p:
The Shepheard seekes the Sheepe, and not the
Sheepe the Shepheard; but I seeke my Master, and my
Master seekes not me: therefore, I am no Sheepe.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p:
The Sheepe for fodder follow the Shepheard,
the Shepheard for foode followes not the Sheepe: thou
for wages followest thy Master, thy Master for wages
followes not thee: therefore, thou art a Sheepe.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Such another proofe will make me cry baâ.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p:
But do'st thou heare: gau'st thou my Letter
to Iulia?

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p:
I Sir: I (a lost‑Mutton) gaue your Letter to her
(a lac'd‑Mutton) and she (a lac'd‑Mutton) gaue mee (a
lost‑Mutton) nothing for my labour.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p:
Here's too small a Pasture for such store of
Muttons.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p:
If the ground be ouer‑charg'd, you were best
sticke her.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p:
Nay, in that you are astray: 'twere best pound
you.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p:
Nay Sir, lesse then a pound shall serue me for car­rying
your Letter.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: You mistake; I meane the pound, a Pinfold.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.l: From a pound to a pin? fold it ouer and ouer,
'Tis threefold too little for carrying a letter to your louer

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: But what said she?

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: I.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: Nod‑I, Why that's noddy.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.l: You mistooke Sir: I say she did nod;
And you aske me if she did nod, and I say I.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: And that set together is noddy.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p:
Now you haue taken the paines to set it toge­
ther, take it for your paines.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: No, no, you shall haue it for bearing the letter.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Well, I perceiue I must be faine to bear with you.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: Why Sir, how doe you beare with me?

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.l: Marry Sir, the letter very orderly,
Hauing nothing but the word noddy for my paines.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: Beshrew me, but you haue a quicke wit.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: And yet it cannot ouer‑take your slow purse.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p:
Come, come, open the matter in briefe; what
said she.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p:
Open your purse, that the money, and the matter
may be both at once deliuered.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: Well Sir: here is for your paines: what said she?

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Truely Sir, I thinke you'll hardly win her.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: Why? could'st thou perceiue so much from her?

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.l: Sir, I could perceiue nothing at all from her;
No, not so much as a ducket for deliuering your letter:
And being so hard to me, that brought your minde;
I feare she'll proue as hard to you in telling your minde.
Giue her no token but stones, for she's as hard as steele.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: What said she, nothing?

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.l: No, not so much as take this for thy pains:

To testifie your bounty, I thank you, you haue cestern'd
(me;
In requital whereof, henceforth, carry your letters your
selfe; And so, Sir, I'le commend you to my Master.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Go, go, be gone, to saue your Ship from wrack,
Which cannot perish hauing thee aboarde,
Being destin'd to a drier death on shore;
I must goe send some better Messenger,
I feare my Iulia would not daigne my lines,
Receiuing them from such a worthlesse post.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: But say Luceita (now we are alone)
Would'st thou then counsaile me to fall in loue?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I Madam, so you stumble not vnheedfully.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Of all the faire resort of Gentlemen,
That euery day with par'le encounter me,
In thy opinion which is worthiest loue?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Please you repeat their names; ile shew my minde,
According to my shallow simple skill.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.p: What thinkst thou of the faire sir Eglamoure?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: As of a Knight, well‑spoken, neat, and fine;
But were I you, he neuer should be mine.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.p: What think'st thou of the rich Mercatio?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Well of his wealth; but of himself, so, so.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.p: What think'st thou of the gentle Protheus?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Lord, Lord: to see what folly raignes in vs.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.p: How now? what meanes this passion at his name?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Pardon deare Madam; 'tis a passing shame
That I (vnworthy body as I am)
Should censure thus on louely Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.p: Why not on Protheus, as of all the rest?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Then thus: of many good, I thinke him best.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: Your reason?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: I haue no other but a womans reason:
I thinke him so, because I thinke him so.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: And would'st thou haue me cast my loue on him?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: I: if you thought your loue not cast away.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: Why he, of all the rest, hath neuer mou'd me.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Yet he, of all the rest, I thinke best loues ye.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: His little speaking, shewes his loue but small.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Fire that's closest kept, burnes most of all.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: They doe not loue, that doe not shew their loue.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Oh, they loue least, that let men know their loue.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: I would I knew his minde.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Peruse this paper Madam.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: To Iulia: Say, from whom?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: That the Contents will shew.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: Say, say: who gaue it thee?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Sir Valentines page: & sent I think from Protheus;
He would haue giuen it you, but I being in the way,
Did in your name receiue it: pardon the fault I pray.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Now (by my modesty) a goodly Broker:
Dare you presume to harbour wanton lines?
To whisper, and conspire against my youth?
Now trust me, 'tis an office of great worth,
And you an officer fit for the place:
There: take the paper: see it be return'd,
Or else returne no more into my sight.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: To plead for loue, deserues more fee, then hate.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: Will ye be gon?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: That you may ruminate.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: And yet I would I had ore‑look'd the Letter;
It were a shame to call her backe againe,
And pray her to a fault, for which I chid her.
What 'foole is she, that knowes I am a Maid,
And would not force the letter to my view?
Since Maides, in modesty, say no to that,
Which they would haue the profferer construe, I.
Fie, fie: how way‑ward is this foolish loue;
That (like a testie Babe) will scratch the Nurse,
And presently, all humbled kisse the Rod?
How churlishly, I chid Lucetta hence,
When willingly, I would haue had her here?
How angerly I taught my brow to frowne,
When inward ioy enforc'd my heart to smile?
My pennance is, to call Lucetta backe
And aske remission, for my folly past.
What hoe: Lucetta.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: What would your Ladiship?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: Is't neere dinner time?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: I would it were,
That you might kill your stomacke on your meat,
And not vpon your Maid.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: What is't that you
Tooke vp so gingerly?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Nothing.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.p: Why didst thou stoope then?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: To take a paper vp, that I let fall.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: And is that paper nothing?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Nothing concerning me.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: Then let it lye, for those that it concernes.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Madam, it will not lye where it concernes,
Vnlesse it haue a false Interpreter.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: Some loue of yours, hath writ to you in Rime.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: That I might sing it (Madam) to a tune:
Giue me a Note, your Ladiship can set

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: As little by such toyes, as may be possible:
Best sing it to the tune of Light O, Loue.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: It is too heauy for so light a tune.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.p: Heauy? belike it hath some burden then?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: I: and melodious were it, would you sing it,

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.p: And why not you?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: I cannot reach so high.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Let's see your Song:
How now Minion?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Keepe tune there still; so you will sing it out:
And yet me thinkes I do not like this tune.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.p: You doe not?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: No (Madam) tis too sharpe.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.p: You (Minion) are too saucie.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Nay, now you are too flat;
And marre the concord, with too harsh a descant:
There wanteth but a Meane to fill your Song.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.p: The meane is dround with you vnruly base.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Indeede I bid the base for Protheus.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: This babble shall not henceforth trouble me;
Here is a coile with protestation:
Goe, get you gone: and let the papers lye:
You would be fingring them, to anger me.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: She makes it strãge strange , but she would be best pleas'd
To be so angred with another Letter.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Nay, would I were so angred with the same:
Oh hatefull hands, to teare such louing words;
Iniurious Waspes, to feede on such sweet hony,
And kill the Bees that yeelde it, with your stings:
Ile kisse each seuerall paper, for amends:
Looke, here is writ, kinde Iulia: vnkinde Iulia,
As in reuenge of thy ingratitude,
I throw thy name against the bruzing-stones,
Trampling contemptuously on thy disdaine.
And here is writ, Loue wounded Protheus.
Poor wounded name: my bosome, as a bed,
Shall lodge thee till thy wound be throughly heal'd;
And thus I search it with a soueraigne kisse.
But twice, or thrice, was Protheus written downe:
Be calme (good winde) blow not a word away,
Till I haue found each letter, in the Letter,
Except mine own name: That, some whirle‑winde beare
Vnto a ragged, fearefull, hanging Rocke,
And throw it thence into the raging Sea.
Loe, here in one line is his name twice writ:
Poore forlorne Protheus, passionate Protheus:
To the sweet Iulia: that ile teare away:
And yet I will not, sith so prettily
He couples it, to his complaining Names;
Thus will I fold them, one vpon another;
Now kisse, embrace, contend, doe what you will.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Madam: dinner is ready: and your father staies.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.p: Well, let vs goe.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: What, shall these papers lye, like Tel‑tales here?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.p: If you respect them; best to take them vp.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Nay, I was taken vp, for laying them downe.
Yet here they shall not lye, for catching cold.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.p: I see you haue a months minde to them.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: I (Madam) you may say what sights you see;
I see things too, although you iudge I winke.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.p: Come, come, wilt please you goe.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Tell me Panthino, what sad talke was that,
Wherewith my brother held you in the Cloyster?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: 'Twas of his Nephew Protheus, your Sonne.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Why? what of him?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: He wondred that your Lordship
Would suffer him, to spend his youth at home,
While other men, of slender reputation
Put forth their Sonnes, to seeke preferment out.
Some to the warres, to try their fortune there;
Some, to discouer Islands farre away:
Some, to the studious Vniuersities;
For any, or for all these exercises,
He said, that Protheus, your sonne, was meet;
And did request me, to importune you
To let him spend his time no more at home;
Which would be great impeachment to his age,
In hauing knowne no trauaile in his youth.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Nor need'st thou much importune me to that
Whereon, this month I haue bin hamering.
I haue consider'd well, his losse of time,
And how he cannot be a perfect man,
Not being tryed, and tutord in the world:
Experience is by industry atchieu'd,
And perfected by the swift course of time:
Then tell me, whether were I best to send him?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: I thinke your Lordship is not ignorant
How his companion, youthfull Valentine,
Attends the Emperour in his royall Court.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I know it well.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l:
'Twere good, I thinke, your Lordship sent him
(thither,
There shall he practise Tilts, and Turnaments;
Heare sweet discourse, conuerse with Noble‑men,
And be in eye of euery Exercise
Worthy his youth, and noblenesse of birth.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I like thy counsaile: well hast thou aduis'd:
And that thou maist perceiue how well I like it,
The execution of it shall make knowne;
Euen with the speediest expedition,
I will dispatch him to the Emperors Court.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: To morrow, may it please you, Don Alphonso,
With other Gentlemen of good esteeme
Are iournying, to salute the Emperor,
And to commend their seruice to his will.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Good company: with them shall Protheus go:
And in good time: now will we breake with him.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Sweet Loue, sweet lines, sweet life,
Here is her hand, the agent of her heart;
Here is her oath for loue, her honors paune;
O that our Fathers would applaud our loues
To seale our happinesse with their consents.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: Oh heauenly Iulia.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: How now? What Letter are you reading there?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: May't please your Lordship, 'tis a word or two
Of commendations sent from Valentine;
Deliuer'd by a friend, that came from him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Lend me the Letter: Let me see what newes.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: There is no newes (my Lord) but that he writes
How happily he liues, how well­belou'd,
And daily graced by the Emperor;
Wishing me with him, partner of his fortune.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: And how stand you affected to his wish?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: As one relying on your Lordships will,
And not depending on his friendly wish.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: My will is something sorted with his wish:
Muse not that I thus sodainly proceed;
For what I will, I will, and there an end:
I am resolu'd that thou shalt spend some time
With Valentinus, in the Emperors Court:
What maintenance he from his friends receiues,
Like exhibition thou shalt haue from me,
To morrow be in readinesse, to goe,
Excuse it not: for I am peremptory.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: My Lord I cannot be so soone prouided,
Please you deliberate a day or two.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Look what thou want'st shalbe sent after thee:
No more of stay: to morrow thou must goe;
Come on, Panthmo; you shall be imployd,
To hasten on his Expedition.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Thus haue I shund the fire, for feare of burning,
And drench'd me in the sea, where I am drown'd.
I fear'd to show my Father Iulias Letter,
Least he should take exceptions to my loue,
And with the vantage of mine owne excuse
Hath he excepted most against my loue.
Oh, how this spring of loue resembleth
The vncertaine glory of an Aprill day,
Which now shewes all the beauty of the Sun,
And by and by a clowd takes all away.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Sir Protheus, your Fathers call's for you;
He is in hast, therefore I pray you go.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Why this it is: my heart accords thereto,
And yet a thousand times it answer's no.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: Sir, your Gloue.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Not mine: my Gloues are on.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Why then this may be yours: for this is but one.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Ha? Let me see: I, giue it me, it's mine:
Sweet ornament, that deckes a thing diuine,
Ah, Siluia, Siluia.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: Madam Siluia: Madam Siluia.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: How now Sirha?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: Shee is not within hearing Sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Why sir, who bad you call her?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: Your worship sir, or else I mistooke.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Well: you'll still be too forward.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: And yet I was last chidden for being too slow.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Goe to, sir; tell me: do you know Madam Siluia?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: Shee that your worship loues?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Why, how know you that I am in loue?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
Marry, by these speciall markes: first, you haue
learn'd (like Sir Protheus) to wreath your Armes like a
Male‑content: to rellish a Loue‑song, like a Robin‑red‑breast:
to walke alone like one that had the pestilence:
to sigh, like a Schoole‑boy that had lost his A. B. C. to
weep like a yong wench that had buried her Grandam:
to fast, like one that takes diet: to watch, like one that
feares robbing: to speake puling, like a beggar at Hal­
low‑Masse: You were wont, when you laughed, to crow
like a cocke; when you walk'd, to walke like one of the
Lions: when you fasted, it was presently after dinner:
when you look'd sadly, it was for want of money: And
now you are Metamorphis'd with a Mistris, that when I
looke on you, I can hardly thinke you my Master.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Are all these things perceiu'd in me?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: They are all perceiu'd without ye.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Without me? they cannot.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
Without you? nay, that's certaine: for with­
out you were so simple, none else would: but you are
so without these follies, that these follies are within you,
and shine through you like the water in an Vrinall: that
not an eye that sees you, but is a Physician to comment
on your Malady.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: But tell me: do'st thou know my Lady Siluia?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: Shee that you gaze on so, as she sits at supper?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Hast thou obseru'd that? euen she I meane.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: Why sir, I know her not.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
Do'st thou know her by my gazing on her, and
yet know'st her not?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: Is she not hard‑fauour'd, sir?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Not so faire (boy) as well fauour'd.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: Sir, I know that well enough.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: What dost thou know?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
That shee is not so faire, as (of you) well‑fa­
uourd?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I mean that her beauty is exquisite
But her fauour infinite.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
That's because the one is painted, and the o­
ther out of all count.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: How painted? and how out of count?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
Marry sir, so painted to make her faire, that no
man counts of her beauty.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: How esteem'st thou me? I account of her beauty.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: You neuer saw her since she was deform'd.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: How long hath she beene deform'd?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: Euer since you lou'd her.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I haue lou'd her euer since I saw her,
And still I see her beautifull.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: If you loue her, you cannot see her.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
Because Loue is blinde: O that you had mine
eyes, or your owne eyes had the lights they were wont
to haue, when you chidde at Sir Protheus, for going vn­
garter'd.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: What should I see then?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
Your owne present folly, and her passing de­formitie:
for hee beeing in loue, could not see to garter
his hose; and you, beeing in loue, cannot see to put on
your hose.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l:
Belike (boy) then you are in loue, for last mor­
(ning
You could not see to wipe my shooes.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
True sir: I was in loue with my bed, I thanke
you, you swing'd me for my loue, which makes mee the bolder
The two Gentlemen of Uerona.
bolder to chide you, for yours.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: In conclusion, I stand affected to her.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
I would you were set, so your affection would
cease.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Last night she enioyn'd me,
To write some lines to one she loues.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: And haue you?

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.p: I haue.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: Are they not lamely writt?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: No (Boy) but as well as I can do them:
Peace, here she comes.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: Oh excellent motion; Oh exceeding Puppet:
Now will he interpret to her.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Madam & Mistres, a thousand good‑morrows.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
Oh, 'giue ye‑good‑ev'n: heer's a million of
manners.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Sir Valentine, and seruant, to you two thousand.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: He should giue her interest: & she giues it him.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: As you inioynd me; I haue writ your Letter
Vnto the secret, nameles friend of yours:
Which I was much vnwilling to proceed in,
But for my duty to your Ladiship.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p:
I thanke you (gentle Seruant) 'tis very Clerkly‑
(done.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Now trust me (Madam) it came hardly‑off:
For being ignorant to whom it goes,
I writ at randome, very doubtfully.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Perchance you think too much of so much pains?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
No (Madam) so it steed you, I will write
(Please you command) a thousand times as much:
sp.l: And yet⸺

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: A pretty period: well: I ghesse the sequell;
And yet I will not name it: and yet I care not.
And yet, take this againe: and yet I thanke you:
Meaning henceforth to trouble you no more.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: And yet you will: and yet, another yet.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What meanes your Ladiship?
Doe you not like it?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Yes, yes; the lines are very queintly writ,
But (since vnwillingly) take them againe.
Nay, take them.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Madam, they are for you.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I, I: you writ them Sir, at my request,
But I will none of them: they are for you:
I would haue had them writ more mouingly:

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Please you, Ile write your Ladiship another.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: And when it's writ: for my sake read it ouer,
And if it please you, so: if not: why, so:

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: If it please me, (Madam?) what then?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Why if it please you, take it for your labour;
And so good‑morrow Seruant.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: Oh Iest vnseene: inscrutible: inuisible,
As a nose on a mans face, or a Weathercocke on a steeple:
My master sues to her: and she hath taught her Sutor,
He being her Pupill, to become her Tutor.
Oh excellent deuise, was there euer heard a better?
That my master being scribe,
To himselfe should write the Letter?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: How now Sir?
What are you reasoning with your selfe?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: Nay: I was riming: 'tis you yt that haue the reason.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: To doe what?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: To be a spokes‑man from Madam Siluia.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: To whom?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: To your selfe: why, she woes you by a figure.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: What figure?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: By a Letter, I should say.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Why she hath not writ to me?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: What need she,
When shee hath made you write to your selfe?
Why, doe you not perceiue the iest?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: No, beleeue me.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: No beleeuing you indeed sir:
But did you perceiue her earnest?

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.p: She gaue me none, except an angry word.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: Why she hath giuen you a Letter.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: That's the Letter I writ to her friend.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: And yt letter hath she deliuer'd, & there an end.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I would it were no worse.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: Ile warrant you, 'tis as well:
For often haue you writ to her: and she in modesty,
Or else for want of idle time, could not againe reply,
Or fearing else some messēger messenger , yt might her mind discouer

Her self hath taught her Loue himself, to write vnto her
(louer.
All this I speak in print, for in print I found it.
Why muse you sir? 'tis dinner time.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.p: I haue dyn'd.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
I, but hearken sir: though the Cameleon Loue
can feed on the ayre, I am one that am nourish'd by my
victuals; and would faine haue meate: oh bee not like
your Mistresse, be moued, be moued.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: Haue patience, gentle Iulia:

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: I must where is no remedy.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: When possibly I can, I will returne.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: If you turne not: you will return the sooner:
Keepe this remembrance for thy Iulia's sake.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Why then wee'll make exchange;
Here, take you this.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: And seale the bargaine with a holy kisse.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Here is my hand, for my true constancie:
And when that howre oer­slips me in the day,
Wherein I sigh not (Iulia) for thy sake,
The next ensuing howre, some foule mischance
Torment me for my Loues forgetfulnesse:
My father staies my coming; answere not:
The tide is now; nay, not thy tide of teares,
That tide will stay me longer then I should,
Iulia, farewell: what, gon without a word?
I, so true loue should doe: it cannot speake,
For truth hath better deeds, then words to grace it.

sp.speaker: Panth.
sp.p: Sir Protheus: you are staid for.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Goe: I come, I come:
sp.p: Alas, this parting strikes poore Louers dumbe.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p:
Nay, 'twill bee this howre ere I haue done
weeping: all the kinde of the Launces, haue this very
fault: I haue receiu'd my proportion, like the prodigious sonne,
The two Gentlemen of Uerona.
Sonne, and am going with Sir Protheus to the Imperialls
Court: I think Crab my dog, be the sowrest natured
dogge that liues: My Mother weeping: my Father
wayling: my Sister crying: our Maid howling: our
Catte wringing her hands, and all our house in a great
perplexitie, yet did not this cruell­hearted Curre shedde
one teare: he is a stone, a very pibble stone, and has no
more pitty in him then a dogge: a Iew would haue wept
to haue seene our parting: why, my Grandam hauing
no eyes, look you, wept her selfe blinde at my parting:
nay, Ile shew you the manner of it. This shooe is my fa­
ther: no, this left shooe is my father; no, no, this left
shooe is my mother: nay, that cannot bee so neyther:
yes; it is so, it is so, it hath the worser sole: this shooe
with the hole in it, is my mother: and this my father:
a veng'ance on't, there 'tis. Now sir, this staffe is my si­
ster: for, looke you, she is as white as a lilly, and as
small as a wand: this hat is Nan our maid: I am the
dogge: no, the dogge is himselfe, and I am the dogge:
oh, the dogge is me, and I am my selfe: I, so, so: now
come I to my Father; Father, your blessing: now
should not the shooe speake a word for weeping:
now should I kisse my Father; well, hee weepes on:
Now come I to my Mother: Oh that she could speake
now, like a would‑woman: well, I kisse her: why
there 'tis; heere's my mothers breath vp and downe:
Now come I to my sister; marke the moane she makes:
now the dogge all this while sheds not a teare: nor
speakes a word: but see how I lay the dust with my
teares.

sp.speaker: Panth.
sp.p:
Launce, away, away: a Boord: thy Master is
ship'd, and thou art to post after with oares; what's the
matter? why weep'st thou man? away asse, you'l loose
the Tide, if you tarry any longer.

sp.speaker: Laun.
sp.p:
It is no matter if the tide were lost, for it is the
vnkindest Tied, that euer any man tied.

sp.speaker: Panth.
sp.p: What's the vnkindest tide?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Why, he that's tide here, Crab my dog.

sp.speaker: Pant.
sp.p:
Tut, man: I meane thou'lt loose the flood, and,
in loosing the flood, loose thy voyage, and in loosing thy
voyage, loose thy Master, and in loosing thy Master,
loose thy seruice, and in loosing thy seruice:—why
dost thou stop my mouth?

sp.speaker: Laun.
sp.p: For feare thou shouldst loose thy tongue.

sp.speaker: Panth.
sp.p: Where should I loose my tongue?

sp.speaker: Laun.
sp.p: In thy Tale.

sp.speaker: Panth.
sp.p: In thy Taile.

sp.speaker: Laun.
sp.p:
Loose the Tide, and the voyage, and the Ma­
ster, and the Seruice, and the tide: why man, if the Riuer
were drie, I am able to fill it with my teares: if the winde
were downe, I could driue the boate with my sighes.

sp.speaker: Panth.
sp.p:
Come: come away man, I was sent to call
thee.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Sir: call me what thou dar'st.

sp.speaker: Pant.
sp.p: Wilt thou goe?

sp.speaker: Laun.
sp.p: Well, I will goe.

div.head: Scena Quarta.
[Act 2, Scene 4]
div.stage: Enter Valentine, Siluia, Thurio, Speed, Duke, Protheus.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Seruant.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Mistris.

sp.speaker: Spee.
sp.p: Master, Sir Thurio frownes on you.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I Boy, it's for loue.

sp.speaker: Spee.
sp.p: Not of you.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Of my Mistresse then.

sp.speaker: Spee.
sp.p: 'Twere good you knockt him.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Seruant, you are sad.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Indeed, Madam, I seeme so.

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.p: Seeme you that you are not?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Hap'ly I doe.

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.p: So doe Counterfeyts.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: So doe you.

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.p: What seeme I that I am not?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Wise.

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.p: What instance of the contrary?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Your folly.

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.p: And how quoat you my folly?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I quoat it in your Ierkin.

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.p: My Ierkin is a doublet.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Well then, Ile double your folly.

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: What, angry, Sir Thurio, do you change colour?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Giue him leaue, Madam, he is a kind of Camelion.

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.p:
That hath more minde to feed on your bloud,
than liue in your ayre.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You haue said Sir.

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.p: I Sir, and done too for this time.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I know it well sir, you alwaies end ere you begin.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: A fine volly of words, gentlemē gentlemen , & quickly shot off.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: 'Tis indeed, Madam; we thank the giuer.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Who is that Seruant?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Your selfe (sweet Lady) for you gaue the fire,
Sir Thurio borrows his wit from your Ladiships lookes,
And spends what he borrowes kindly in your company.

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.p:
Sir, if you spend word for word with me, I shall
make your wit bankrupt.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l:
I know it well sir: you haue an Exchequer of
(words,
And, I thinke, no other treasure to giue your followers:
For it appears by their bare Liueries
That they liue by your bare words.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: No more, gentlemen, no more:
Here comes my father.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Now, daughter Siluia, you are hard beset.
Sir Valentine, your father is in good health,
What say you to a Letter from your friends
Of much good newes?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: My Lord, I will be thankfull,
To any happy messenger from thence.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: Know ye Don Antonio, your Countriman?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I, my good Lord, I know the Gentleman
To be of worth, and worthy estimation,
And not without desert so well reputed.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: Hath he not a Sonne?

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.l: I, my good Lord, a Son, that well deserues
The honour, and regard of such a father.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: You know him well?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I knew him as my selfe: for from our Infancie
We haue conuerst and spent our howres together,
And though my selfe haue beene an idle Trewant,
Omitting the sweet benefit of time
To cloath mine age with Angel‑like perfection:
Yet hath Sir Protheus (for that's his name)
Made vse, and faire aduantage of his daies:
His yeares but yong, but his experience old:
His head vn‑mellowed, but his Iudgement ripe;
And, in a word (for far behinde his worth
Comes all the praises that I now bestow.)
He is compleat in feature, and in minde,
With all good grace, to grace a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Beshrew me sir, but if he make this good
He is as worthy for an Empresse loue,
As meet to be an Emperors Councellor:
Well, Sir: this Gentleman is come to me
With Commendation from great Potentates,
And heere he meanes to spend his time a while,
I thinke 'tis no vn‑welcome newes to you.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.p: Should I haue wish'd a thing, it had beene he.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p:
Welcome him then according to his worth:
Siluia, I speake to you, and you Sir Thurio,
sp.l: For Ualentine, I need not cite him to it,
I will send him hither to you presently.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: This is the Gentleman I told your Ladiship
Had come along with me, but that his Mistresse
Did hold his eyes, lockt in her Christall lookes.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Be‑like that now she hath enfranchis'd them
Vpon some other pawne for fealty.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Nay sure, I thinke she holds them prisoners stil.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Nay then he should be blind, and being blind
How could he see his way to seeke out you?

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.p: Why Lady, Loue hath twenty paire of eyes.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: They say that Loue hath not an eye at all.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: To see such Louers, Thurio, as your selfe,
Vpon a homely obiect, Loue can winke.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Haue done, haue done: here comes yͤ gentleman.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Welcome, deer Protheus: Mistris, I beseech you
Confirme his welcome, with some speciall fauor.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: His worth is warrant for his welcome hether,
If this be he you oft haue wish'd to heare from.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.l: Mistris, it is: sweet Lady, entertaine him
To be my fellow‑seruant to your Ladiship.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Too low a Mistres for so high a seruant.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Not so, sweet Lady, but too meane a seruant
To haue a looke of such a worthy a Mistresse.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Leaue off discourse of disabilitie:
Sweet Lady, entertaine him for your Seruant.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: My dutie will I boast of, nothing else.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: And dutie neuer yet did want his meed.
Seruant, you are welcome to a worthlesse Mistresse.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: Ile die on him that saies so but your selfe.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: That you are welcome?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: That you are worthlesse.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p:
Madam, my Lord your father wold speak with
(you.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I wait vpon his pleasure: Come Sir Thurio,
Goe with me: once more, new Seruant welcome;
Ile leaue you to confer of home affaires,
When you haue done, we looke too heare from you.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: Wee'll both attend vpon your Ladiship.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Now tell me: how do al from whence you came?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: Your frends are wel, & haue thē them much cōmended.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: And how doe yours?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: I left them all in health.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: How does your Lady? & how thriues your loue?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: My tales of Loue were wont to weary you,
I know you ioy not in a Loue‑discourse.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I Protheus, but that life is alter'd now,
I haue done pennance for contemning Loue,
Whose high emperious thoughts haue punish'd me
With bitter fasts, with penitentiall grones,
With nightly teares, and daily hart‑sore sighes,
For in reuenge of my contempt of loue,
Loue hath chas'd sleepe from my enthralled eyes,
And made them watchers of mine owne hearts sorrow.
O gentle Protheus, Loue's a mighty Lord,
And hath so humbled me, as I confesse
There is no woe to his correction,
Nor to his Seruice, no such ioy on earth:
Now, no discourse, except it be of loue:
Now can I breake my fast, dine, sup, and sleepe,
Vpon the very naked name of Loue.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Enough; I read your fortune in your eye:
Was this the Idoll, that you worship so?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Euen She; and is she not a heauenly Saint?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: No; But she is an earthly Paragon.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Call her diuine.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: I will not flatter her.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.p: O flatter me: for Loue delights in praises.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: When I was sick, you gaue me bitter pils,
And I must minister the like to you.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Then speake the truth by her; if not diuine,
Yet let her be a principalitie,
Soueraigne to all the Creatures on the earth.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: Except my Mistresse.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Sweet: except not any,
Fxcept thou wilt except against my Loue.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: Haue I not reason to prefer mine owne?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And I will help thee to prefer her to:
Shee shall be dignified with this high honour,
To beare my Ladies traine, lest the base earth
Should from her vesture chance to steale a kisse,
And of so great a fauor growing proud,
Disdaine to roote the Sommer‑swelling flowre,
And make rough winter euerlastingly.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: Why Ualentine, what Bragadisme is this?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Pardon me (Protheus) all I can is nothing,
To her, whose worth, make other worthies nothing;
Shee is alone.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: Then let her alone.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Not for the world: why man, she is mine owne,
And I as rich in hauing such a Iewell
As twenty Seas, if all their sand were pearle,
The water, Nectar, and the Rocks pure gold.
Forgiue me that I doe not dreame on thee,
Because thou seest me doate vpon my loue:
My foolish Riuall that her Father likes
(Onely for his possessions are so huge)
Is gone with her along, and I must after,
For Loue (thou know'st is full of iealousie.)

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: But she loues you?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l:
I, and we are betroathd: nay more, our mariage
(howre,
With all the cunning manner of our flight
Determin'd of: how I must climbe her window,
The Ladder made of Cords, and all the means
Plotted, and 'greed on for my happinesse.
Good Protheus goe with me to my chamber,
In these affaires to aid me with thy counsaile.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Goe on before: I shall enquire you forth:
I must vnto the Road, to dis‑embarque
Some necessaries, that I needs must vse,
And then Ile presently attend you.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Will you make haste?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: I will.
Euen as one heate, another heate expels,
Or as one naile, by strength driues out another.
So the remembrance of my former Loue
Is by a newer obiect quite forgotten,
It is mine, or Valentines praise?
Her true perfection, or my false transgression?
That makes me reasonlesse, to reason thus?
Shee is faire: and so is Iulia that I loue,
(That I did loue, for now my loue is thaw'd,
Which like a waxen Image 'gainst a fire
Beares no impression of the thing it was.)
Me thinkes my zeale to Valentine is cold,
And that I loue him not as I was wont:
O, but I loue his Lady too­too much,
And that's the reason I loue him so little.
How shall I doate on her with more aduice,
That thus without aduice begin to loue her?
'Tis but her picture I haue yet beheld,
And that hath dazel'd my reasons light:
But when I looke on her perfections,
There is no reason, but I shall be blinde.
If I can checke my erring loue, I will,
If not, to compasse her Ile vse my skill.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: Launce, by mine honesty welcome to Padua.

sp.speaker: Laun.
sp.p:
Forsweare not thy selfe, sweet youth, for I am
not welcome. I reckon this alwaies, that a man is neuer
vndon till hee be hang'd, nor neuer welcome to a place,
till some certaine shot be paid, and the Hostesse say wel­
come.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
Come‑on you mad‑cap: Ile to the Ale­house
with you presently; where, for one shot of fiue pence,
thou shalt haue fiue thousand welcomes: But firha, how
did thy Master part with Madam Iulia?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p:
Marry after they cloas'd in earnest, they parted
very fairely in lest.

sp.speaker: Spee.
sp.p: But shall she marry him?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Spee.
sp.p: How then? shall he marry her?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: No, neither.

sp.speaker: Spee.
sp.p: What, are they broken?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: No; they are both as whole as a fish.

sp.speaker: Spee.
sp.p: Why then, how stands the matter with them?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p:
Marry thus, when it stands well with him, it
stands well with her.

sp.speaker: Spee.
sp.p: What an asse art thou, I vnderstand thee not.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: What a blocke art thou, that thou canst not?
My staffe vnderstands me?

sp.speaker: Spee.
sp.p: What thou saist?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p:
I, and what I do too: looke thee, Ile but leane,
and my staffe vnderstands me.

sp.speaker: Spee.
sp.p: It stands vnder thee indeed.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Why, stand‑vnder: and vnder‑stand is all one.

sp.speaker: Spee.
sp.p: But tell me true, wil't be a match?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p:
Aske my dogge, if he say I, it will: if hee say
no, it will: if hee shake his taile, and say nothing, it
will.

sp.speaker: Spee.
sp.p: The conclusion is then, that it will.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p:
Thou shalt neuer get such a secret from me, but
by a parable.

sp.speaker: Spee.
sp.p:
'Tis well that I get it so: but Launce, how saist
thou that that my master is become a notable Louer?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: I neuer knew him otherwise.

sp.speaker: Spee.
sp.p: Then how?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p:
A notable Lubber: as thou reportest him to
bee.

sp.speaker: Spee.
sp.p: Why, thou whorson Asse, thou mistak'st me,

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p:
Why Foole, I meant not thee, I meant thy
Master.

sp.speaker: Spee.
sp.p: I tell thee, my Master is become a hot Louer.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p:
Why, I tell thee, I care not, though hee burne
himselfe in Loue. If thou wilt goe with me to the Ale­
house: if not, thou art an Hebrew, a Iew, and not worth
the name of a Christian.

sp.speaker: Spee.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p:
Because thou hast not so much charity in thee as
to goe to the Ale with a Christian: Wilt thou goe?

sp.speaker: Spee.
sp.p: At thy seruice.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: To leaue my Iulia; shall I be forsworne?
To loue faire Siluia; shall I be forsworne?
To wrong my friend, I shall be much forsworne.
And ev'n that Powre which gaue me first my oath
Prouokes me to this three‑fold periurie.
Loue bad mee sweare, and Loue bids me for‑sweare;
O sweet‑suggesting Loue, if thou hast sin'd,
Teach me (thy tempted subiect) to excuse it.
At first I did adore a twinkling Starre,
But now I worship a celestiall Sunne:
Vn‑heedfull vowes may heedfully be broken,
And he wants wit, that wants resolued will,
To learne his wit, t'exchange the bad for better;
Fie, fie, vnreuerend tongue, to call her bad,
Whose soueraignty so oft thou hast preferd,
With twenty thousand soule‑confirming oathes,
I cannot leaue to loue; and yet I doe:
But there I leaue to loue, where I should loue.
Iulia I loose, and Valentine I loose,
If I keepe them, I needs must loose my selfe:
If I loose them, thus finde I by their losse,
For Valentine, my selfe: for Iulia, Siluia.
I to my selfe am deerer then a friend,
For Loue is still most precious in it selfe,
And Siluia (witnesse heauen that made her faire)
Shewes Iulia but a swarthy Ethiope.
I will forget that Iulia is aliue,
Remembring that my Loue to her is dead.
And Valentine Ile hold an Enemie,
Ayming at Siluia as a sweeter friend.
I cannot now proue constant to my selfe,
Without some treachery vs'd to Valentine.
This night he meaneth with a Corded‑ladder
To climbe celestiall Siluia's chamber window,
My selfe in counsaile his competitor.
Now presently Ile giue her father notice
Of their disguising and pretended flight:
Who (all inrag'd) will banish Valentine:
For Thurio he intends shall wed his daughter,
But Valentine being gon, Ile quickely crosse
By some slie tricke, blunt Thurio's dull proceeding.
Loue lend me wings, to make my purpose swift
At thou hast lent me wit, to plot this drift.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Counsaile, Lucetta, gentle girle assist me,
And eu'n in kinde loue, I doe coniure thee,
Who art the Table wherein all my thoughts
Are visibly Character'd, and engrau'd,
To lesson me, and tell me some good meane
How with my honour I may vndertake
A iourney to my louing Protheus.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Alas, the way is wearisome and long.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: A true‑deuoted Pilgrime is not weary
To measure Kingdomes with his feeble steps,
Much lesse shall the that hath Loues wings to flie,
And when the flight is made to one so deere,
Of such diuine perfection as Sir Protheus.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Better forbeare, till Protheus make returne.

sp.speaker: Iul:
sp.l: Oh, know'st yu not, his looks are my foules food?
Pitty the dearth that I haue pined in,
By longing for that food so long a time.
Didst thou but know the inly touch of Loue,
Thou wouldst as soone goe kindle fire with snow
As seeke to quench the fire of Loue with words.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I doe not seeke to quench your Loues hot fire,
But qualifie the fires extreame rage,
Lest it should burne aboue the bounds of reason.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: The more thou dam'st it vp, the more it burnes:
The Current that with gentle murmure glides
(Thou know'st) being stop'd, impatiently doth rage:
But when his faire course is not hindered,
He makes sweet musicke with th'enameld stones,
Giuing a gentle kisse to euery sedge
He ouer‑taketh in his pilgrimage.
And so by many winding nookes he straies
With willing sport to the wilde Ocean.
Then let me goe, and hinder not my course:
Ile be as patient as a gentle streame,
And make a pastime of each weary step,
Till the last step haue brought me to my Loue,
And there Ile rest, as after much turmoile
A blessed soule doth in Elizium.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: But in what habit will you goe along?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Not like a woman, for I would preuent
The loose encounters of lasciuious men:
Gentle Lucetta, fit me with such weedes
As may beseeme some well reputed Page.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Why then your Ladiship must cut your haire.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: No girle, Ile knit it vp in silken strings,
With twentie od‑conceited true‑loue knots:
To be fantastique, may become a youth
Of greater time then I shall shew to be.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
What fashion (Madam) shall I make your bree­
(ches?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: That fits as well, as tell me (good my Lord)
What compasse will you weare your Farthingale?
Why eu'n what fashion thou best likes (Lucetta.)

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
You must needs haue thē them with a cod‑peece (Ma­
(dam)

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: Out, out, (Lucetta) that wilbe illfauourd.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: A round hose (Madam) now's not worth a pin
Vnlesse you haue a cod‑peece to stick pins on.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Lucetta, as thou lou'st me let me haue
What thou think'st meet, and is most mannerly.
But tell me (wench) how will the world repute me
For vndertaking s? vnstaid a iourney?
I feare me it will make me scandaliz'd.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: If you thinke so, then stay at home, and go not.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: Nay, that I will not.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Then neuer dreame on Infamy, but go:
If Protheus like your iourney, when you come,
No matter who's displeas'd, when you are gone:
I feare me he will scarce be pleas'd with all.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: That is the least (Lucetta) of my feare:
A thousand oathes, an Ocean of his teares,
And instances of infinite of Loue,
Warrant me welcome to my Protheus.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: All these are seruants to deceitfull men.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Base men, that vse them to so base effect;
But truer starres did gouerne Protheus birth,
His words are bonds, his oathes are oracles,
His loue sincere, his thoughts immaculate,
His teares, pure messengers, sent from his heart,
His heary as far from fraud, as heauen from earth.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Pray heau'n he proue so when you come to him.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Now, as thou lou'st me, do him not that wrong,
To beare a hard opinion of his truth:
Onely deserue my loue, by louing him,
And presently goe with me to my chamber
To take a note of what I stand in need of,
To furnish me vpon my longing iourney:
All that is mine I leaue at thy dispose,
My goods, my Lands, my reputation,
Onely, in lieu thereof, dispatch me hence:
Come; answere not: but to it presently,
I am impatient of my tarriance.

div.head: Actus Tertius, Scena Prima.
[Act 3, Scene 1]
div.stage:
Enter Duke, Thurio, Protheus, Valentine,
Launce, Speed.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Sir Thurio, giue vs leaue (I pray) a while,
We haue some secrets to confer about.
Now tell me Protheus, what's your will with me?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: My gracious Lord, that which I wold discouer,
The Law of friendship bids me to conceale,
But when I call to minde your gracious fauours
Done to me (vndeseruing as I am)
My dutie pricks me on to vtter that
Which else, no worldly good should draw from me:
Know (worthy Prince) Sir Valentine my friend
This night intends to steale away your daughter:
My selfe am one made priuy to the plot.
I know you haue determin'd to bestow her
On Thurio, whom your gentle daughter hates,
And should she thus be stolne away from you,
It would be much vexation to your age.
Thus (for my duties sake) I rather chose
To crosse my friend in his intended drift,
Then (by concealing it) heap on your head
A pack of sorrowes, which would presse you downe
(Being vnpreuented) to your timelesse graue.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Protheus, I thank thee for thine honest care,
Which to requite, command me while I liue.
This loue of theirs, my selfe haue often seene,
Haply when they haue iudg'd me fast asleepe,
And oftentimes haue purpos'd to forbid
Sir Ualentine her companie, and my Court.
But fearing lest my iealous ayme might erre,
And so (vnworthily) disgrace the man
(A rashnesse that I euer yet haue shun'd)
I gaue him gentle lookes, thereby to finde
That which thy selfe hast now disclos'd to me.
And that thou maist perceiue my feare of this,
Knowing that tender youth is soone suggested,
I nightly lodge her in an vpper Towre,
The key whereof, my selfe haue euer kept:
And thence she cannot be conuay'd away.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Know (noble Lord) they haue deuis'd a meane
How he her chamber‑window will ascend,
And with a Corded‑ladder fetch her downe:
For which, the youthfull Louer now is gone,
And this way comes he with it presently.
Where (if it please you) you may intercept him.
But (good my Lord) doe it so cunningly
That my discouery be not aimed at:
For, loue of you, not hate vnto my friend,
Hath made me publisher of this pretence.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Vpon mine Honor, he shall neuer know
That I had any light from thee of this.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: Adiew, my Lord, Sir Valentine is comming.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: Sir Valentine, whether away so fast?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Please it your Grace, there is a Messenger
That stayes to beare my Letters to my friends,
And I am going to deliuer them.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: Be they of much import?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: The tenure of them doth but signifie
My health, and happy being at your Court.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Nay then no matter: stay with me a while,
I am to breake with thee of some affaires
That touch me neere: wherein thou must be secret.
'Tis not vnknown to thee, that I haue sought
To match my friend Sir Thurio, to my daughter.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I know it well (my Lord) and sure the Match
Were rich and honourable: besides, the gentleman
Is full of Vertue, Bounty, Worth, and Qualities
Beseeming such a Wife, as your faire daughter:
Cannot your Grace win her to fancie him?

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: No, trust me, She is peeuish, sullen, froward,
Prowd, disobedient, stubborne, lacking duty,
Neither regarding that she is my childe,
Nor fearing me, as if I were her father:
And may I say to thee, this pride of hers
(Vpon aduice) hath drawne my loue from her,
And where I thought the remnant of mine age
Should haue beene cherish'd by her child‑like dutie,
I now am full resolu'd to take a wife,
And turne her out, to who will take her in:
Then let her beauty be her wedding dowre:
For me, and my possessions she esteemes not.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: What would your Grace haue me to do in this?

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: There is a Lady in Verona heere
Whom I affect: but she is nice, and coy,
And naught esteemes my aged eloquence.
Now therefore would I haue thee to my Tutor
(For long agone I haue forgot to court,
Besides the fashion of the time is chang'd)
How, and which way I may bestow my selfe
To be regarded in her sun‑bright eye.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Win her with gifts, if she respest not words,
Dumbe Iewels often in their silent kinde
More then quicke words, doe moue a womans minde.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: But she did scorne a present that I sent her,

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: A woman somtime scorns what best cōtents contents her.
Send her another: neuer giue her ore,
For scorne at first, makes after‑loue the more.
If she doe frowne, 'is not in hate of you,
But rather to beget more loue in you.
If she doe chide, 'tis not to haue you gone,
For why, the fooles are mad, if left alone.
Take no repulse, what euer she doth say,
For, get you gon, she doth not meane away.
Flatter, and praise, commend, extoll their graces:
Though nere so blacke, say they haue Angells faces,
That man that hath a tongue, I say is no man,
If with his tongue he cannot win a woman.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: But she I meane, is promis'd by her friends
Vnto a youthfull Gentleman of worth,
And kept seuerely from resort of men,
That no man hath accesse by day to her.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Why then I would resort to her by night.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: I, but the doores be lockt, and keyes kept safe,
That no man hath recourse to her by night.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.p: What letts but one may enter at her window?

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Her chamber is aloft, far from the ground,
And built so sheluing, that one cannot climbe it
Without apparant hazard of his life.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.l: Why then a Ladder quaintly made of Cords
To cast vp, with a paire of anchoring hookes,
Would serue to scale another Hero's towre,
So bold Leander would aduenture it.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Now as thou art a Gentleman of blood
Aduise me, where I may haue such a Ladder.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: When would you vse it? pray sir, tell me that.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: This very night; for Loue is like a childe
That longs for euery thing that he can come by.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: By seauen a clock, ile get you such a Ladder.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: But harke thee: I will goe to her alone,
How shall I best conuey the Ladder thither?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: It will be light (my Lord) that you may beare it
Vnder a cloake, that is of any length.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: A cloake as long as thine will serue the turne?

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.p: I my good Lord.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Then let me see thy cloake,
Ile get me one of such another length.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Why any cloake will serue the turn (my Lord)

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: How shall I fashion me to weare a cloake?
I pray thee let me feele thy cloake vpon me.
What Letter is this same? what's here? to Siluia?
And heere an Engine fit for my proceeding,
Ile be so bold to breake the scale for once.
My thoughts do harbour with my Siluia nightly,
And slaues they are to me, that send them flying.
Oh, could their Master come, and goe as lightly,
Himselfe would lodge where (senceles) they are lying.
My Herald Thoughts, in thy pure bosome rest‑them,
While I (their King) that thither them importune
Doe curse the grace, that with such grace hath blest them,
Because my selfe doe want my seruants fortune.
I curse my selfe, for they are sent by me,
That they should harbour where their Lord should be.
What's here? Siluia, this night 1 will enfranchise thee.
'Tis so: and heere's the Ladder for the purpose.
Why Phaeton (for thou art Merops sonne)
Wilt thou aspire to guide the heauenly Car?
And with thy daring folly burne the world?
Wilt thou reach stars, bccause they shine on thee?
Goe base Intruder, ouer‑weening Slaue,
Bestow thy fawning smiles on equall mates,
And thinke my patience, (more then thy desert)
Is priuiledge for thy departure hence.
Thanke me for this, more then for all the fauors
Which (all too‑much) I haue bestowed on thee.
But if thou linger in my Territories
Longer then swiftest expedition
Will giue thee time to leaue our royall Court,
By heauen, my wrath shall farre exceed the loue
I euer bore my daughter, or thy selfe.
Be gone, I will not heare thy vaine excuse,
But as thou lou'st thy life, make speed from hence.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And why not death, rather then liuing torment?
To die, is to be banisht from my selfe,
And Siluia is my selfe: banish'd from her
Is selfe from selfe. A deadly banishment:
What light, is light, if Siluia be not seene?
What ioy is ioy, if Siluia be not by?
Vnlesse it be to thinke that she is by
And feed vpon the shadow of perfection.
Except I be by Siluia in the night,
There is no musicke in the Nightingale.
Vnlesse I looke on Siluia in the day,
There is no day for me to looke vpon.
Shee is my essence, and I leaue to be;
If I be not by her faire influence
Foster'd, illumin'd, cherish'd, kept aliue.
I flie not death, to flie his deadly doome,
Tarry I heere, I but attend on death,
But flie I hence, I flie away from life.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: Run (boy) run, run, and seeke him out.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: So‑hough, Soa hough⸺

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: What seest thou?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Him we goe to finde,
There's not a haire on's head, but t'is a Valentine.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: Valentine?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: Who then? his Spirit?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Neither,

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.p: Nothing.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Can nothing speake? Master, shall I strike?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: Who wouldst thou strike?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Nothing.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: Villaine, forbeare.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Why Sir, Ile strike nothing: I pray you.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: Sirha, I say forbeare: friend Valentine, a word.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: My eares are stopt, cannot hear good newes,
So much of bad already hath possest them.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Then in dumbe silence will I bury mine,
For they are harsh, vn‑tuneable, and bad.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Is Siluia dead?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: No, Valentine.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: No Valentine indeed, for sacred Siluia,
Hath she forsworne me?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: No, Ualentine.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.l: No Valentine, if Siluia haue forsworne me.
What is your newes?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Sir, there is a proclamation, yt you are vanished.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: That thou art banish'd: oh that's the newes,
From hence, from Siluia, and from me thy friend.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Oh, I haue fed vpon this woe already,
And now excesse of it will make me surfet.
Doth Siluia know that I am banish'd?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: I, I: and she hath offered to the doome
(Which vn‑reuerst stands in effectuall force)
A Sea of melting pearle, which some call teares;
Thoseat her fathers churlish feete she tenderd,
With them vpon her knees, her humble selfe,
Wringing her hands, whose whitenes so became them,
As if but now they waxed pale for woe:
But neither bended knees, pure hands held vp,
Sad sighes, deepe grones, nor siluer‑shedding teares
Could penetrate her vncompassionate Sire;
But Valentine, if he be tane, must die.
Besides, her intercession chaf'd him so,
When she for thy repeale was suppliant,
That to close prison he commanded her,
With many bitter threats of biding there.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: No more: vnles the next word that thou speak'st
Haue some malignant power vpon my life:
If so: I pray thee breath it in mine eare,
As ending Antheme of my endlesse dolor.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Cease to lament for that thou canst not helpe,
And study helpe for that which thou lament'st,
Time is the Nurse, and breeder of all good;
Here, if thou stay, thou canst not see thy loue:
Besides, thy staying will abridge thy life:
Hope is a louers staffe, walke hence with that
And manage it, against despairing thoughts:
Thy letters may be here, though thou art hence,
Which, being writ to me, shall be deliuer'd
Euen in the milke‑white bosome of thy Loue.
The time now serues not to expostulate,
Come, Ile conuey thee through the City‑gate,
And ere I part with thee, confer at large
Of all that may concerne thy Loue‑affaires:
As thou lou'st Siluia (though not for thy selfe)
Regard thy danger, and along with me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I pray thee Launce, and if thou seest my Boy
Bid him make haste, and meet me at the North‑gate.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: Goe sirha, finde him out: Come Ualentine.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Oh my deere Siluia; haplesse Valentine.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p:
I am but a foole, looke you, and yet I haue
the wit to thinke my Master is a kinde of a knaue: but
that's all one, if he be but one knaue: He liues not now
that knowes me to be in loue, yet I am in loue, but a
Teeme of horse shall not plucke that from me: nor who
'tis I loue: and yet 'tis a woman; but what woman, I
will not tell my selfe: and yet 'tis a Milke‑maid: yet 'tis
not a maid: for shee hath had Gossips: yet 'tis a maid,
for she is her Masters maid, and serues for wages. Shee
hath more qualities then a Water‑Spaniell, which is
much in a bare Christian: Heere is the Cate‑log of her
Condition. Inprimis, Shee can fetch and carry: why
a horse can doe no more; nay, a horse cannot fetch, but
onely carry, therefore is shee better then a Iade. Item.
She can milke, looke you, a sweet vertue in a maid with
cleane hands.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p:
How now Signior Launce? what newes with
your Mastership?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: With my Mastership? why, it is at Sea:

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p:
Well, your old vice still: mistake the word: what
newes then in your paper?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: The black'st newes that euer thou heard'st.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Why man? how blacke?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Why, as blacke as Inke.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Let me read them?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Fie on thee Iolt‑head, thou canst not read.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Thou lyest: I can.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I will try thee: tell me this: who begot thee?

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Marry, the son of my Grand‑father.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p:
Oh illiterate loyterer; it was the sonne of thy
Grand‑mother: this proues that thou canst not read.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Come fool, come: try me in thy paper.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: There: and S. Nicholas be thy speed.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Inprimis she can milke.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I that she can.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Item, she brews good Ale.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p:
And thereof comes the prouerbe: (Blessing of
your heart, you brew good Ale.)

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Item, she can sowe.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: That's as much as to say (Can she so?)

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Item she can knit.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: What neede a man care for a stock with a wench,
When she can knit him a stock?

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Item, she can wash and scoure.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p:
A speciall vertue: for then shee need not be
wash'd, and scowr'd.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Item, she can spin.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p:
Then may I set the world on wheeles, when she
can spin for her liuing.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Item, she hath many namelesse vertues.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p:
That's as much as to say Bastard‑vertues: that
indeede know not their fathers; and therefore haue no
names.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Here follow her vices.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Close at the heels of her vertues.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p:
Item, shee is not to be fasting, in respect of her
breath.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p:
Well: that fault may be mended with a break­
fast: read on.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Item, she hath a sweet mouth.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: That makes amends for her soure breath.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Item, she doth talke in her sleepe.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p:
It's no matter for that; so shee sleepe not in her
talke.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Item, she is slow in words.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Oh villaine, that set this downe among her vices;
To be slow in words, is a womans onely vertue.
I pray thee, out with't, and place it for her chiefe vertue.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Item, she is proud.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Out with that too:
It was Eues legacie, and cannot be t'ane from her.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Item, she hath no teeth.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I care not for that neither: because I loue crusts.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Item, she is curst.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Well: the best is, she hath no teeth to bite.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Item, she will often praise her liquor.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: If her liquor be good, she shall: if she will not,
I will; for good things should be praised.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Item, she is too liberall.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p:
Of her tongue she cannot; for that's writ downe
she is slow of: of her purse, shee shall not, for that ile
keepe shut: Now, of another thing shee may, and that
cannot I helpe. Well, proceede.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p:
Item, shee hath more haire than wit, and more
faults then haires, and more wealth then faults.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p:
Stop there: Ile haue her: she was mine, and not
mine, twice or thrice in that last Article: rehearse that
once more.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Item, she hath more haire then wit.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p:
More haire then wit: it may be ile proue it: The
couer of the salt, hides the salt, and therefore it is more
then the salt; the haire that couers the wit, is more
then the wit; for the greater hides the lesse: What's
next?

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.l: And more faults then haires.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: That's monstrous: oh that that were out.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: And more wealth then faults.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p:
Why that word makes the faults gracious:
Well, ile haue her: and if it be a match, as nothing is
impossible.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p:
Why then, will I tell thee, that thy Master staies
for thee at the North gate.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: For me?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p:
For thee? I, who art thou? he hath staid for a bet­
ter man than thee.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: And must I goe to him?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p:
Thou must run to him; for thou hast staid so long,
that going will scarce serue the turne.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p:
Why didst not tell me sooner? 'pox of your loue
Letters.

sp.speaker: La.
Du.
sp.l: Sir Thurio, feare not, but that she will loue you
Now Valentine is banish'd from her sight.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Since his exile she hath despis'd me most,
Forsworne my company and rail'd at me,
That I am desperate of obtaining her.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: This weake impresse of Loue, is as a figure
Trenched in ice, which with an houres heate
Dissolues to water, and doth loose his forme.
A little time will melt her frozen thoughts,
And worthlesse Valentine shall be forgot.
How now sir Protheus, is your countriman
(According to our Proclamation) gon?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: Gon, my good Lord.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: My daughter takes his going grieuously?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: A little time (my Lord) will kill that griefe.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: So I beleeue: but Thurio thinkes not so:
Protheus, the good conceit I hold of thee,
(For thou hast showne some signe of good desert)
Makes me the better to confer with thee.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Longer than I proue loyall to your Grace,
Let me not live, to looke vpon your Grace.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Thou know'st how willingly, I would effect
The match betweene sir Thurio, and my daughter.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: I doe my Lord.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: And also, I thinke, thou art not ignorant
How she opposes her against my will?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: She did my Lord, when Ualentine was here.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I, and peruersly, she perseuers so:
What might we doe to make the girle forget
The loue of Valentine, and loue sir Thurio?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: The best way is, to slander Ualentine,
With falsehood, cowardize, and poore discent:
Three things, that women highly hold in hate.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: I, but she'll thinke that it is spoke in hate.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: I, if his enemy deliuer it.
Therefore it must with circumstance be spoken
By one, whom she esteemeth as his friend.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Then you must vndertake to slander him.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: And that (my Lord) I shall be loath to doe:
'Tis an ill office for a Gentleman,
Especially against his very friend.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Where your good word cannot aduantage him,
Your slander neuer can endamage him;
Therefore the office is indifferent,
Being entreated to it by your friend.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: You haue preuail'd (my Lord) if I can doe it
By ought that I can speake in his dispraise,
She shall not long continue loue to him:
But say this weede her loue from Valentine,
It followes not that she will loue sir Thurio.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Therefore, as you vnwind her loue from him;
Least it should rauell, and be good to none,
You must prouide to bottome it on me:
Which must be done, by praising me as much
As you, in worth dispraise, sir Ualentine.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: And Protheus, we dare trust you in this kinde,
Because we know (on Valentines report)
You are already Loues firme votary,
And cannot soone reuolt, and change your minde.
Vpon this warrant, shall you haue accesse
Where you, with Siluia, may conferre at large.
For she is lumpish, heauy, mellancholly,
And (for your friends sake) will be glad of you;
Where you may temper her, by your perswasion,
To hate yong Ualentine, and loue my friend.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: As much as I can doe, I will effect:
But you sir Thurio, are not sharpe enough:
You must lay Lime, to tangle her desires
By walefull Sonnets, whose composed Rimes
Should be full fraught with seruiceable vowes.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: I, much is the force of heauen‑bred Poesie.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Say that vpon the altar of her beauty
You sacrifice your teares, your sighes, your heart:
Write till your inke be dry; and with your teares
Moist it againe, and frame some feeling line,
That may discouer such integrity:
For Orpheus Lute, was strung with Poets sinewes,
Whose golden touch could soften steele and stones,
Make Tygers tame, and huge Leuiathans
Forsake vnsounded deepes, to dance on Sands.
After your dire‑lamenting Elegies,
Visit by night your Ladies chamber‑window
